title: RL34490
content: The FY2009 Omnibus Appropriations Act, P.L. 111-8, enacted on March 11, 2009, provides $4.40 billion for the legislative branch, a 10.88% increase over FY2008. The enacted level was $258.47 million less than the requested $4.66 billion. Funding was initially at FY2008 levels until the act was passed. The House subcommittee marked up its version of the FY2009 legislative branch bill with a proposal of approximately $3.4 billion. The annual legislative branch appropriations bill usually contains two titles, with Title I including appropriations for various legislative branch agencies. Title II of the legislative branch appropriations bill contains general administrative provisions and appropriations for legislative branch entities. For example, the FY2003 Act included funds for the John C. Stennis Center for Public Service Training and Development and the Congressional Award Act. Sometimes a third title may be included for other provisions, such as the continuity of representation in the House of Representatives in "extraordinary circumstances" in the FY2006 Act. Prior to FY2003, the bill was structured differently with Title I focusing on Congressional Operations. Title II of the legislative branch appropriations bill includes budget authority for various agencies supporting Congress, such as the Botanic Garden, Library of Congress, Government Printing Office, and Government Accountability Office. This funding is separate from Title I, which covers direct support for Congress. The legislative branch appropriations bill historically included additional titles for capital improvements and special functions. The House Subcommittee on Legislative Branch handled this bill until changes were made in the 109th Congress. The Subcommittee was abolished in 2005 but reestablished in 2007 for the 110th Congress. The FY2009 U.S. Budget requested $4.7 billion in new budget authority. The FY2009 U.S. Budget requested $4.7 billion in new budget authority for legislative branch activities, an 18% increase from FY2008. The increase was mainly for mandatory expenses like salary adjustments and increased retirement contributions. Both houses considered separate budget allocations for discretionary and mandatory funds. The House allocated $4.404 billion in discretionary budget authority and $127 million in mandatory budget authority, while the Senate allocated $4.402 billion in discretionary funds and $127 million in mandatory funds. The revised Senate allocation for the FY2009 U.S. Budget is $4.402 billion in discretionary funds and $127 million in mandatory budget authority. The House Appropriations Subcommittee on Legislative Branch held budget hearings for various agencies, including the Architect of Capitol, Library of Congress, and U.S. Capitol Police. The Senate Appropriations Subcommittee also held a hearing on the budget requests of the Architect of the Capitol, U.S. Capitol Police, and the Library of Congress. Public witnesses, including representatives of legislative branch employee unions, also provided input during the hearings. The House subcommittee held a markup on June 23, 2008, proposing $3.4 billion in funding. The FY2009 Omnibus Appropriations Act provided $895.0 million for Senate operations, an increase of $63.3 million. The Senate had requested $940.9 million for its internal operations. Appropriations for Senate committees are contained in two accounts, with the Omnibus providing $137.4 million. The Senate requested $142.6 million for the Committee on Appropriations account, receiving $15.2 million in the Omnibus. Each Senator's Official Personnel and Office Expense Account includes funds for office administration. The Omnibus provided $400.0 million, $25.6 million less than requested. The House received $1.30 billion for internal operations, less than the $1.33 billion requested. The FY2009 Omnibus Appropriations Act provided funding for House committees, with $154.0 million allocated for personnel and nonpersonnel expenses, an increase of 16.1% from the previous year. The Committee on Appropriations received $31.3 million, representing a 5.3% increase. The Members' Representational Allowance saw a 5.1% increase to $609.0 million. The FY2009 Omnibus provided $609.0 million, a 5.1% increase from FY2008. The Green the Capitol Initiative aimed to reduce the House's environmental impact by operating carbon-neutrally, cutting energy consumption by 50%, and promoting sustainability. The CAO requested funding for the Green the Capitol Initiative in FY2008 and FY2009 to implement sustainability measures in House operations. The FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $3.9 million for green initiatives, including funding for new light bulbs, an E-85 gasoline pump, and the Capitol Power Plant. Additionally, an amendment allowed the CAO to use the revolving fund for environmental activities. The FY2009 Omnibus budget includes $305.75 million for the Capitol Police, an 8.5% increase from FY2008. The Green the Capitol Initiative received $1 million, with directives for online hearings, extended hours for facilities, and improving the child care center playground. Efforts to increase House-wide data sharing standards are also being reported on. The Capitol Police requested $333.7 million for FY2009, representing a 5.8% increase from FY2008. The budget includes funds for salaries, overtime pay, hazardous duty pay, government contributions, and various expenses such as vehicles, security equipment, training programs, and travel. The Capitol Police budget for FY2009 includes $248.0 million for salaries and $57.8 million for general expenses, with an increase in both categories compared to FY2008. Additionally, there is a separate appropriation for Capitol Police buildings and grounds within the Architect of the Capitol account, with a 27.2% increase in funding for FY2009. The FY2009 Omnibus bill allows for the transfer of appropriations between headings, but a requested provision for law enforcement retirement status for Capitol Police criminal investigators was not granted. The Capitol Police were directed to analyze their vehicle fleet and justify the use of vehicles driven home by officers. Chief Phillip Morse faced questions about background investigations on employees. The restructuring of the USCP Office of Financial Management and the force's ability to handle increased staffing and security responsibilities were also discussed. The Senate subcommittee hearing focused on factors driving USCP overtime. The Senate subcommittee hearing discussed factors driving the USCP overtime budget and the costs of overtime versus hiring new officers. The Architect of the Capitol oversees maintenance and operations of the Capitol Complex, including various buildings and grounds. The AOC is responsible for the Supreme Court buildings as well, but their expenses are not part of the legislative branch appropriations bill. The Architect of the Capitol's operations are funded through ten accounts, with the FY2009 Omnibus providing $529.6 million, an increase of $116.1 million (28%) from FY2008. The AOC had requested $642.7 million in new budget authority, representing a 55.4% increase. The FY2008 budget authority decreased by 8.1% from FY2007. The AOC received $40.2 million for the Capitol Visitor Center, including $31.1 million for the project. The Capitol Visitor Center project received an increase of $10.9 million (54%) and operational costs saw an increase of $9.1 million (7.4%). Both subcommittees showed interest in the completion of the Visitor Center, which opened to the public in December 2008. Discussions included transportation plans for large groups visiting the Capitol and the condition of the Capitol Power Plant utility tunnels. Funding for repairs followed a complaint issued in February 2006. The funding for repairs in the Capitol Power Plant utility tunnels was prompted by a complaint issued in February 2006 by the Office of Compliance. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) also highlighted potential hazards in the tunnels, such as excessive heat, asbestos, falling concrete, lack of egress, and communication issues. A settlement agreement was reached in May 2007 to address these concerns. The settlement agreement for the complaint and citations regarding the Capitol Power Plant utility tunnels was discussed in multiple hearings by the House and Senate Appropriations Committees in 2006, 2007, and 2008. Concerns about unsafe working conditions and tunnel safety were raised by various committees, leading to emergency appropriations for repairs in FY2006 and FY2007. The FY2009 Omnibus provides $56.4 million for the tunnel program, less than the $126.65 million requested by the Architect of the Capitol. A program for the collection and sale of recyclable materials from the Capitol Complex is also established. The FY2009 Omnibus provides funding for the tunnel program and establishes a program for recycling materials at the Capitol Complex. The Architect of the Capitol is directed to improve staff-led tour training and report on increasing diversity at the Capitol Visitor Center. Additional provisions requested by the AOC were not granted. The FY2009 Omnibus provides funding for various projects requested by the Architect of the Capitol, including allowing the AOC to establish a student loan repayment program, lease property for the Library of Congress, retain funds from energy savings, grant compensatory time off to employees, extend Capitol grounds, establish an AOC Senior Executive Service, and maintain sidewalks in additional areas. Stephen Ayers testified before the House subcommittee on the AOC budget request, addressing deferred maintenance backlog. The Senate subcommittee discussed the $127 million request for utility tunnel repairs under the FY2009 Omnibus, questioning the need for the funding and implications of any lack of it. The Architect's prioritization of fire- and life-safety projects, including the role of the Office of Compliance, was also a focus. CBO received $44.1 million under the FY2009 Omnibus for providing objective economic and budgetary analysis to Congress. CBO received $44.1 million under the FY2009 Omnibus, an increase of $6.8 million from the previous year. The funding includes support for 15 additional positions for health care analysis and congressional priorities. Director Peter R. Orszag emphasized the need to expand CBO's capacity in health economics. The Library of Congress provides research support for Congress through various services. The Library of Congress receives funding for various programs including acquisitions, preservation, legal research, administration of copyright laws, policy analysis, and providing reading material to the blind. The FY2009 Omnibus provides $607.1 million for the Library, an increase of 7.8% from the previous year. This includes salaries and expenses totaling $412.7 million, with additional authority to spend $6.35 million in receipts. The FY2009 Omnibus provides funding for various Library of Congress programs, including Copyright Office, Congressional Research Service, Books for the Blind, and Library buildings and grounds. The total funding is $607.1 million, with specific allocations for each program showing increases compared to previous years. The FY2009 Omnibus provides $607.1 million in funding for Library of Congress programs, including a 42.2% increase for buildings and grounds. The Omnibus also includes administrative provisions for the Library, such as an incentive awards program and funding for revolving fund activities. Additionally, former Members of Congress can continue serving on the Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial Commission. Language in the explanatory statement requires reports on various topics, including the creation of an Asian American and Pacific Islander Collection and the cost of tuition at the Library of Congress child care center. The FY2009 Omnibus provides funding for Library of Congress programs, including digitization of American texts in Arabic, Persian, Pashtu, and Indonesian, and preservation of the Alan Lomax Collection. Discussions on funding for the Books for the Blind program and technology updates were held. The Library expressed concern over lost funds for the National Digital Information Infrastructure and Preservation Program and requested $6 million for FY2009. The FY2009 Omnibus provides $7.5 million for the Library of Congress program, an increase from the requested $6 million. The Congressional Research Service (CRS) received $107.3 million, a 4.6% increase from the previous year. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) received $531.0 million, a 6.3% increase from the previous year. The FY2009 Omnibus provided $531.0 million for the Government Accountability Office (GAO), an increase of 6.3% from the previous year. An additional $25 million was allocated in the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. GAO is required to conduct bimonthly reviews of states and localities on fund usage and have access to records related to contracts awarded with the funds. The Omnibus also repealed and modified certain GAO reporting requirements. Funding for technology assessments and the Comptroller General's annuity were addressed in the Congressional Record statement. The closure of the Office of Technology Assessment in 1972 led to periodic reexamination of funding for scientific studies by the legislative branch. The FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $2.5 million to GAO for technology assessments, with funding continuing for these studies. The House Appropriations Committee proposed repealing separate retirement benefits for the Comptroller General in favor of the standard Federal Employees Retirement System. The House subcommittee revisited the issue of Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS) during the FY2009 appropriations hearings. The explanatory statement requires GAO to contract with the National Academy of Public Administration for further review of the Comptroller General's annuity. Gene L. Dodaro testified in support of the GAO budget request at a House hearing. The House subcommittee discussed staffing issues including diversity, recruitment, retention, and succession planning. The FY2009 Omnibus provides $140.6 million for the Government Printing Office, an increase of 12.7% over the previous year. The Government Printing Office (GPO) received $96.8 million for congressional printing and binding, $38.7 million for the Office of Superintendent of Documents, and nearly $5 million for the revolving fund in FY2009, which were increases from the previous year's funding levels. The FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act did not include an appropriation for the revolving fund at GPO, which had requested $33 million. The congressional printing and binding account covers expenses for congressional use and distribution of government publications. This includes the Congressional Record, U.S. Code, committee reports, and other documents. The Office of Superintendent of Documents account funds the mailing of government documents for Members of Congress and federal agencies, as authorized by law. The budget authority for the revolving fund was requested to support information technology and GPO facilities, including $10 million for the Federal Digital System (FDsys). Public Printer Robert C. Tapella testified before the House Legislative Branch Subcommittee in support of the GPO. The Office of Compliance testified in support of the GPO FY2009 budget request before the House Legislative Branch Subcommittee. Key issues discussed included staffing, discrimination lawsuits, environmental efforts, facility request, digital transformation, funding for printing, and passport production. The Office of Compliance administers the Congressional Accountability Act, applying employment and workplace safety laws to Congress and certain legislative branch entities. The FY2009 Omnibus provides a 21.8% increase in funding for the Office of Compliance. The FY2009 Omnibus provides $4.1 million for the Office of Compliance, a 21.8% increase from FY2008. The office had requested $4.3 million. Progress on asbestos abatement and settlement agreement with the Architect of the Capitol was discussed during a House hearing. The Office of Compliance supports the Architect's request for nearly $127 million for the settlement agreement implementation. Funding request for education and outreach was also questioned. The Office of Compliance was directed to establish procedures to improve communication and documentation. The Open World Leadership Center administers a program supporting democratic changes in other countries by allowing their leaders to observe democracy and free enterprise in the United States. Established in 2000 as the Center for Russian Leadership Development, it was renamed the Open World Leadership Center in 2003 to include more countries. The Open World Leadership Center program was expanded to include additional countries designated by the board of trustees. The center receives services from the Library of Congress through an inter-agency agreement. The FY2009 Omnibus provided $13.9 million for Open World. There were discussions in 2008 about whether the program should be located within the legislative branch or the executive branch. Ambassador John O'Keefe testified about the program's reach and effectiveness. The Open World Leadership Center program, funded by the FY2009 Omnibus, may attract a wider audience if not associated with a specific administration. Discussions have been held on potentially transferring the program to the executive branch or establishing it as an independent agency. There is also consideration to expand the list of countries hosting participants to include Iraq and Afghanistan. The Board of Trustees is directed to collaborate with the State Department and Judiciary for shared funding. The Stennis Center, established in 1988 to promote public service by congressional staff, received $430,000 in FY2009 Omnibus funding. The Board of Trustees is directed to collaborate with the State Department and Judiciary for shared funding.
